title: 108_s2584
content: The Act titled "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" provides a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" offers a 50% credit on the basis of qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. The maximum credit for eligible persons is $30,000 per year. The credit for property placed in service by eligible persons or farmer-owned entities under the Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 is limited to $30,000 per year, reduced by creditable investments. Farmer-owned entities can receive a credit based on the eligible person's investments in the entity when the property is placed in service. The term 'creditable investments' refers to the qualified investments made by an eligible person in a farmer-owned entity, reduced by previous investments taken into account under this section. The term 'qualified value-added agricultural property' refers to property eligible for investment by an individual in farmer-owned entities, with a limit of $30,000 in aggregate investments per taxable year. The term 'qualified value-added agricultural property' refers to property used to add value to goods derived from renewable organic matter, with depreciation or amortization allowed, and a determined useful life. The term 'eligible person' in the context of farming business refers to someone who materially participates in an eligible farming business. Material participation is determined similarly to participation in the trade or business of farming. The term 'eligible farming business' refers to a farming business that is not a passive activity and is defined similarly to material participation in the trade or business of farming. The term 'eligible farming business' refers to a farming business that is not a passive activity. A 'farmer-owned entity' is defined as a corporation or partnership where eligible persons own majority voting power and stock/profits. The text discusses the ownership requirements for a partnership or cooperative to be considered eligible farming businesses, where eligible persons must own majority voting power and profits interests. Constructive ownership rules similar to section 263A(e)(2)(B) apply, with family members defined accordingly. The ownership requirements for eligible farming businesses include family members defined as spouse, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren residing in the same household or jointly operating farming businesses. The ownership requirements for eligible farming businesses include family members such as spouse, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren residing in the same household or jointly operating farming businesses. Qualified investments refer to cash payments for purchasing equity in a farmer-owned entity, specifically defined as stock in a domestic corporation acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. The tax provisions allow for the acquisition of stock in a domestic corporation, capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, and patronage interest in a cooperative between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, in exchange for cash. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply. The tax provisions allow for the acquisition of stock in a domestic corporation, capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, and patronage interest in a cooperative between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, in exchange for cash. Special rules apply for married individuals and certain property is not eligible. Rules similar to section 52 apply for allocation of credit in estates and trusts. Rules similar to section 50(b) apply for certain property eligibility. Basis adjustment occurs when a credit is allowed for qualified agricultural property. Recapture rules under section 50(a) apply for certain dispositions within 5 years. Recapture rules under subsection (e) apply if qualified agricultural property is disposed of or no longer qualifies within 5 years of being placed in service. Special rules apply in the event of death regarding the transfer of eligible agricultural property. The period for recapture rules is suspended for 2 years after the death of the eligible person. If an heir is also an eligible person, certain rules do not apply to the transfer of property to the heir. The transfer of eligible agricultural property upon death involves special rules. Recapture rules are suspended for 2 years after the death of the eligible person. Certain rules do not apply to the transfer of property to an heir who is also an eligible person. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. This section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2010. The value-added agricultural property investment credit is included as part of the general business credit for eligible persons. The value-added agricultural property investment credit is part of the general business credit for eligible persons, and can be used against minimum tax. The text discusses amendments to the tax code related to the value-added agricultural property credit. It includes a definition of the credit and limitations on its carryback. Amendments to the tax code include restrictions on carrying back the value-added agricultural property investment credit before the effective date of section 45G. Additionally, a deduction for certain unused business credits is introduced, and a basis adjustment is made. Amendments to the tax code include a basis adjustment and a new value-added agricultural property investment credit. The tax code amendments include a new value-added agricultural property investment credit effective for investments made after December 31, 2004.
